results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based intervention was not recommended for reducing vasomotor symptoms, based on Level II evidence (limited or inconsistent scientific evidence).
population_specificity: Menopausal women experiencing vasomotor symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of mind-body therapies, including mindfulness, for relieving sleep disturbance in cancer patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness had a significant immediate effect on subjective sleep disturbance, with effects lasting at least 6 months. Mindfulness also improved objective sleep outcomes, including sleep onset latency and total sleep time.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with cancer experiencing sleep disturbance.
study_duration: Effects were observed immediately post-intervention and lasted at least 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and acceptability of integrating a meditation intervention into a cardiac rehabilitation program for reducing depression and anxiety symptoms.
results_summary: Meditation was found feasible and acceptable, with improved adherence to the cardiac rehabilitation program, though specific efficacy for symptom reduction was not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease and at least mild depression and/or anxiety symptoms attending cardiac rehabilitation.
effective_dosage: 16-minute guided group meditation once a week for 6 weeks, plus daily self-guided practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore organizational strategies, including mindfulness, to address burnout among pediatricians and pediatric subspecialists related to EHR use.
results_summary: The study found that incorporating mindfulness, along with teamwork and standardized workflows, can help decrease stress from EHR use and improve physician satisfaction and wellbeing. Organizational factors and work culture were more associated with burnout than EHR use itself.
population_specificity: Pediatricians and pediatric subspecialists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction program on maternal stress, well-being, and sleep quality in high-risk pregnant women.
results_summary: The study compared a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction program to a Mediterranean diet intervention and usual care, but the abstract does not provide specific results for the mindfulness group, only noting outcomes for the Mediterranean diet group.
population_specificity: High-risk pregnant women at 19-23 weeks' gestation.
study_duration: Approximately 15-17 weeks (from 19-23 weeks to 34-36 weeks' gestation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai chi versus non-mindful exercise on measures of anxiety, depression, and general mental health, and to examine potential moderators of these effects.
results_summary: Tai chi showed small-to-moderate significant effects in reducing anxiety and depression and improving general mental health compared to non-mindful exercise, with baseline mental health and study quality influencing outcomes.
population_specificity: 4370 participants across 23 studies, including individuals with measures of anxiety (950), depression (1959), and general mental health (1461).
effective_dosage: 1-5 sessions per week, 20-83 min per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Mindfulness-Based Blood Pressure Reduction (MB-BP) compared to enhanced usual care on reducing systolic blood pressure in individuals with elevated BP.
results_summary: MB-BP was associated with a clinically relevant reduction in systolic BP (5.9 mm Hg) and outperformed the control group by 4.5 mm Hg at 6 months. Plausible mechanisms included reduced sedentary activity, improved diet, and increased mindfulness.
population_specificity: Adults with elevated unattended office BP (≥120/80 mm Hg; 58.7% women; 81.1% non-Hispanic White; mean age 59.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to collate quantitative results of studies analyzing the effects of mindfulness-based interventions on various outcomes in medical students and assess how study design and intervention characteristics influenced results.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed statistically significant reductions in stress and distress symptoms and increased mindfulness in intervention groups compared to controls, with effects persisting over months or years. Both long and short courses, as well as face-to-face and non-face-to-face sessions, were effective.
population_specificity: Medical students
effective_dosage: 4- to 10-week courses (original Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction or Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy or modifications)
study_duration: Varied (4-10 weeks, with follow-ups over months or years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a comprehensive Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) in reducing stress, anxiety, and improving well-being among medical students.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced perceived stress, improved mental well-being, emotional regulation, resilience, attentional control, and reduced mind-wandering and overall distress.
population_specificity: Medical students from Italian universities (total sample of 362 students).
effective_dosage: 10 twice-a-week Integral Meditation classes, dietary advice, and brief yoga sessions.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but implied to span the duration of the 10 sessions.

study_goal: The abstract does not address Mindfulness; it focuses on obesity, binge eating disorder, and time-restricted eating.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Mindfulness or its effects.
population_specificity: Not applicable (Mindfulness not studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify neurobiological factors related to psychological outcomes in dementia caregivers and assess whether mindfulness interventions (Mentalizing Imagery Therapy) could improve mood symptoms and brain connectivity.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness interventions increased prefrontal network connectivity and reduced mood symptoms in caregivers. Observational data also linked caregiver psychological outcomes to differences in brain regions involved in socio-affective processing, memory, and stress.
population_specificity: Dementia caregivers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a moderate to high-intensity physical activity program in minimizing insomnia and related symptoms in breast cancer patients, not specifically focusing on mindfulness.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific results regarding mindfulness, as the study primarily investigates the effects of an aerobic exercise program on insomnia and other symptoms in breast cancer patients.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients receiving chemotherapy in France.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on exercise, not mindfulness).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively synthesize the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on reducing body mass index (BMI), waist circumference (WC), weight, and percent body fat (%BF).
results_summary: The study found significant short-term effects of MBIs on reducing BMI, WC, weight, and %BF, with sustained long-term effects on BMI and weight. Mindful movement enhanced weight loss effects compared to interventions without it.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with anthropometric measures).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a brief mindfulness exercise in regular university courses, guided by lecturers, is feasible and has immediate effects on students' mental states.
results_summary: The brief mindfulness exercise was associated with lower stress, higher presence, higher motivation, and better mood in students, with effects persisting throughout the session. Lecturers also reported positive effects from instructing mindfulness.
population_specificity: University students (N=325 at baseline, n=101 at post-measurement) and lecturers (N=14) from six German universities.
study_duration: Weekly observations over a semester (n=1193 student observations, n=160 lecturer observations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of psychosocial interventions, including mindfulness, in reducing psychological distress, anxiety, stress, burnout, depression, and improving sleep quality.
results_summary: Mindfulness- or relaxation-based interventions significantly improved sleep quality but showed no significant effect on post-traumatic stress, burnout, or depression. Mixed results were found for anxiety, with one study showing an effect and another not. A combination of training and mindfulness appeared beneficial for reducing anxiety and stress in home care workers.
population_specificity: Home care workers and general participants in psychosocial intervention studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions on biomarkers of innate and adaptive immunity in adults, compared to control conditions.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based interventions were associated with a post-treatment reduction in proinflammatory cytokines and markers (d = -0.38) and a significant increase in anti-inflammatory cytokines (d = 0.69). The evidence grade for mindfulness was moderate, though substantial heterogeneity was detected.
population_specificity: Adults with inflammation-related conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-guided 12-minute mindfulness meditation (isha kriya) delivered via a mobile app could improve quality of life (QoL) in hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) recipients during the acute post-transplant phase.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in overall QoL or global health scores with isha kriya, but there was a transient, statistically and clinically significant improvement in bone marrow transplantation-specific QoL concerns at day +30 post-HCT, which did not persist by day +100.
population_specificity: Autologous and allogeneic HCT recipients aged ≥18 years, excluding those without smartphone access or regular practitioners of yoga/meditation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and efficacy of video-delivered group Emotion Focused Mindfulness Therapy (EFMT) for older adults with late-life anxiety.
results_summary: The study found that EFMT significantly improved anxiety symptoms compared to a wait-list control group, with high retention and adherence rates. The intervention was deemed feasible, acceptable, and efficacious for reducing late-life anxiety.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥55 years old) living in community settings.
study_duration: 9 weeks (primary endpoint) with follow-up at 17 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether a multimodal environmental enrichment (EE) protocol, including mindfulness in virtual reality, could reduce relapse rates in patients with severe alcohol use disorder (AUD).
results_summary: The study predicted that the EE intervention group, which included mindfulness sessions, would have lower relapse rates compared to the control group, but specific results on mindfulness's effects were not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes included craving reduction and mindfulness skills acquisition, suggesting potential benefits.
population_specificity: Adults receiving treatment for severe alcohol use disorder (AUD).
effective_dosage: Six 40-minute sessions (with mindfulness practiced during the first 20 minutes of each session).
study_duration: 9 days (with sessions spread over this period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of adding an 8-week online mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) to exercise therapy and patient education on clinical and psychological outcomes for people with patellofemoral pain (PFP), and whether psychological factors mediate changes in pain and function.
results_summary: The study found that adding MBI to standard treatment (exercise therapy and education) may improve short- and long-term outcomes by addressing psychological factors, though specific results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: People with patellofemoral pain (PFP).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week MBI program including formal and informal practices).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of psychological interventions, including mindfulness-based interventions, in reducing anxiety, depression, and stress symptoms among college students during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that psychotherapies, including mindfulness, significantly alleviated anxiety, depression, and stress symptoms in university students, with statistically significant results. However, the difference in reducing somatization symptoms was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: College students during the COVID-19 pandemic

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how mindfulness interventions promote well-being through intermediate stages, as proposed by Mindfulness-to-Meaning theory.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that mindfulness interventions may enhance subjective well-being by following a common pathway involving two intermediate stages, though specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, acceptability, adherence, usability, and safety of digital interventions, including mindfulness, for smoking cessation in patients with serious mental illness (SMI).
results_summary: The study found that digital interventions, including mindfulness, varied in effectiveness, with the highest abstinence rates reported but no specific details on mindfulness alone. Outcome measures were inconsistent across studies.
population_specificity: Patients with serious mental illness (SMI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of an interdisciplinary intervention, including Mindfulness, on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and symptoms of anxiety and depression in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that the interdisciplinary intervention, including Mindfulness, significantly improved HRQoL, fatigue, pain, anxiety, and depression in breast cancer survivors compared to usual care, with effects sustained at 3 months post-intervention. Patients reported high satisfaction with the treatment.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (n=60) in a hospital gynaecology and oncology unit.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions (120 min per day, once a week for 6 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of mindfulness and self-compassion training in improving the quality of life for adults with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly greater improvement in skin disease-specific quality of life (DLQI score) and other patient-reported outcomes, including eczema severity, compared to the waiting list group. The standardized effect size was large (Cohen d = -1.06), indicating strong clinical relevance.
population_specificity: Adults with atopic dermatitis (mean age 36.3 years, 79.4% women, mean AD duration 26.6 years).
effective_dosage: Eight 90-minute weekly group sessions of online mindfulness and self-compassion training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of mindfulness and meditation therapies on Parkinson's disease patients, focusing on motor symptoms, cognitive function, and quality of life.
results_summary: Mindfulness and meditation therapies significantly improved motor symptoms (UPDRS-Part III) and cognitive function but showed no significant effects on gait velocity, quality of life, activities of daily living, depression, anxiety, pain, or sleep disturbance.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (337 participants across 8 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT), cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and usual care on chronic pain management in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that 27% of participants used cannabis for pain management, with oil/tincture being the most common route. Cannabis users were slightly younger than non-users, but no direct results on MBCT's efficacy were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with multiple sclerosis (MS) and chronic pain (N = 242).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of integrating meditation, mindfulness, and acceptance (MMA) strategies into individual psychotherapy for adults.
results_summary: Only three studies met inclusion criteria, with limited evidence supporting the efficacy of MMA in individual psychotherapy. The experimental study showed no significant effects, while qualitative studies suggested potential benefits.
population_specificity: Adult samples receiving individual psychotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the direct and long-term effects of a four-week mindfulness-based intervention on mental health outcomes in intensive care unit nurses.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in mindfulness, anxiety, depression, subjective well-being, and emotional exhaustion post-intervention, with some effects maintained at two- and six-month follow-ups.
population_specificity: Intensive care unit nurses in China (90 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short- and long-term efficacy of a mobile-delivered four-immeasurable Mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) on perinatal depression, obstetric, and neonatal outcomes.
results_summary: The mindfulness group showed significant reductions in depression from baseline to post-intervention, sustained until 4-6 weeks postpartum, along with reduced risk of emergent cesarean section and higher Apgar scores in newborns. The intervention also mediated lower emergency cesarean risk through depression reduction before birth.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (average age 30.6 years, mean gestational age 18.8 weeks) suffering from heightened distress.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured at baseline, post-intervention, 37th-week gestation, and 4-6 weeks postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based training programs in reducing psychological distress and promoting well-being among medical students.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based training improved mindfulness, reduced stress and psychological distress symptoms, and enhanced health perception and psychological well-being, though significant heterogeneity among studies was noted.
population_specificity: Medical students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of homework completion on treatment response between Behavioral Activation Treatment for Anhedonia (BATA) and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT) in reducing anhedonia.
results_summary: Both BATA and MBCT significantly and equivalently reduced anhedonia (measured by SHAPS scores). Greater session-to-session homework completion was associated with greater symptom improvement within individuals, but total homework completion did not predict improvements between individuals.
population_specificity: Adults with anhedonia (BATA n=38, MBCT n=35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness as one of three treatment components for reducing smoking for coping motives in individuals with COPD.
results_summary: In Study 1, 3/5 Mindfulness participants met treatment implementation targets, but efficacy was modest compared to other treatments. Study 2 showed high participant satisfaction and feasibility, though specific Mindfulness outcomes were not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) who smoke for coping motives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of mindfulness, alongside other interventions, in preventing and treating childhood obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests that mindfulness, combined with parent education, motivational interviewing, diet, exercise, and sleep improvement, can help alleviate obesity risk in children. The abstract does not provide specific data on mindfulness alone.
population_specificity: Children with or at risk of obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of resilience-building interventions, including mindfulness techniques, for nurses, particularly in care home settings.
results_summary: Thirteen of fifteen studies showed increased resilience scores post-intervention, with mindfulness-based and easily accessible practices demonstrating significant improvements. No studies specifically addressed care home nurses.
population_specificity: Primarily hospital-based nurses in general and specialist contexts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the acceptability and feasibility of an online pain management program combining mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) and exercise for adults with chronic pain, and to assess the feasibility of conducting a randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing this intervention with an online self-management guide.
results_summary: The study found that both the MBSR-exercise intervention (MOVE group) and the self-management guide (SM group) were acceptable and feasible, with higher satisfaction reported in the MOVE group. Both groups showed comparable improvements in pain-related outcomes post-intervention and at a 12-week follow-up.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic pain

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a culturally adapted online Mindfulness Training Course (MTC) for improving stress and wellbeing among Pakistani university students.
results_summary: The study evaluated the feasibility of an RCT design for a mindfulness intervention but did not report specific efficacy outcomes in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Pakistani university students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a BCI-based mindfulness meditation app could improve the experience of patients with atrial fibrillation during radiofrequency catheter ablation by reducing physical and psychological discomfort.
results_summary: The study found that BCI-based app-delivered mindfulness meditation significantly reduced pain, anxiety, and fatigue scores compared to conventional care, and also decreased fentanyl use, though no significant differences were observed in hemodynamic parameters or other sedative doses. The incidence of adverse events was lower in the intervention group, but the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with atrial fibrillation scheduled for radiofrequency catheter ablation (n=84).
effective_dosage: Not specified (app-based intervention administered by a research nurse).
study_duration: Duration of the RFCA procedure (exact length not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to rank the effectiveness of mindfulness compared to physical activity, sleep hygiene, and an active control in reducing psychological distress in university students using an AI-adaptive trial method.
results_summary: The study compared mindfulness, physical activity, sleep hygiene, and an active control, measuring changes in psychological distress (DASS-21 scores). While the abstract does not specify individual intervention results, the adaptive trial design aimed to determine the best-performing intervention and rank their effectiveness.
population_specificity: Australian university students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Internet-delivered mindfulness stress reduction combined with acceptance and commitment therapy (IMSR-ACT) on health anxiety and quality of life in caregivers of COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in health anxiety subscales and improvements in quality of life compared to the control group, with statistically significant results across multiple measures.
population_specificity: Caregivers of COVID-19 patients in Golpayegan city, Iran, with health anxiety scores above 27 on the HAI-18.
effective_dosage: Not specified (techniques delivered over 9 weeks via WhatsApp).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a mindfulness-based psychosomatic intervention on depression, anxiety, fear of childbirth, and life satisfaction in pregnant women.
results_summary: The intervention group showed lower depression levels, reduced anxiety, decreased fear of childbirth, and increased life satisfaction compared to the control group. The mindfulness-based intervention was effective in improving perinatal mental health outcomes.
population_specificity: First-time pregnant women in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of mindfulness-based stress reduction counseling on rejection sensitivity and resilience in patients with thalassemia.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based stress reduction counseling significantly reduced rejection sensitivity and increased resilience in thalassemia patients compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with thalassemia referring to the Kerman Thalassemia Center in Kerman, Iran.
effective_dosage: Eight 60-minute online mindfulness-based stress reduction counseling sessions (one session per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) on the neural correlates of inhibitory control and executive functions (EFs) in elementary school children from a low socioeconomic status background.
results_summary: The study found that children who received the MBI showed improvements in EFs as assessed by questionnaires and increased P3 amplitude associated with successful response inhibition compared to active controls. These results suggest mindfulness practice can enhance inhibitory control and EFs, which are critical for children's social, emotional, and mental health development.
population_specificity: Elementary school children (4th and 5th graders) from a low socioeconomic status school in Santiago de Chile.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based therapies in treating anxiety and depressive disorders in patients with cancer.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based therapies are effective treatments for anxiety and depressive disorders in cancer patients, alongside psychotherapy and cognitive behavioral therapy. Psychopharmacological treatments were also noted as effective.
population_specificity: Patients with cancer experiencing anxiety and depressive disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether manipulating response styles (mindful acceptance vs. attentional avoidance) to simulated voice hearing affects emotional distress, anxiety, and cognitive performance in a non-clinical population.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in distress, anxiety, or cognitive performance between the mindful acceptance and attentional avoidance groups. Adherence to assigned response styles was low, limiting the ability to draw conclusions about the impact of these strategies.
population_specificity: Non-clinical adults (n=101)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based counseling on the childbirth experience and labor pain in primiparous women.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness-based counseling significantly improved childbirth experience scores and reduced labor pain in the intervention group compared to the control group. The results were statistically significant with meaningful clinical differences.
population_specificity: Primiparous women with a gestational age of 32 to 34 weeks in Iran.
effective_dosage: Eight mindfulness-based counseling sessions (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Duration of sessions not specified, but intervention spanned from 32-34 weeks gestation to childbirth.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mindfulness-based programs on pregnant women's fear of childbirth and self-efficacy.
results_summary: Mindfulness-based exercises improved childbirth self-efficacy (low-certainty evidence) and probably reduced fear of childbirth (moderate-certainty evidence) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on psychological outcomes in college and university students during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: MBIs showed a significantly moderate improvement in anxiety and depressive symptoms among college and university students during the pandemic, with clinical relevance for mental health treatment.
population_specificity: College and university students during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) in managing anxiety and depression in adult cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that MBSR, along with other psychosocial interventions, led to improvements in depression and anxiety symptoms in cancer survivors. The evidence for MBSR was based on three systematic reviews and meta-analyses, indicating its efficacy as a therapeutic option.
population_specificity: Adult cancer survivors, with noted underrepresentation of ethnic minority groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of psychobiotics on the Microbiota-Gut-Brain Axis (MGBA) and mental health in healthy adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of Mindfulness.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on quality of life, psychological distress, and cognitive emotion regulation strategies in breast cancer patients undergoing early chemotherapy.
results_summary: The MBSR group showed significantly better outcomes in quality of life, reduced anxiety and depression, and improved cognitive emotion regulation strategies compared to the control group. The intervention enhanced positive psychology and mental adjustment in patients.
population_specificity: 101 patients with breast cancer under early chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Internet-delivered cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and mindfulness-based tinnitus stress reduction (MBTSR) interventions for chronic tinnitus.
results_summary: The study found promising evidence that mindfulness-based interventions can reduce tinnitus-induced distress, with some support for online delivery, but direct comparative efficacy against CBT was not yet established.
population_specificity: Lithuanian-speaking individuals suffering from chronic tinnitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based mobile health app (Mind Guide) in reducing PTSD symptoms and alcohol-related problems among post-9/11 veterans.
results_summary: The beta test showed promising effects, with significant reductions in PTSD symptoms, alcohol use frequency, alcohol-related problems, craving, perceived stress, and improved emotion regulation. Recruitment is ongoing for a larger pilot RCT to further validate these findings.
population_specificity: Post-9/11 veterans with PTSD and alcohol use disorder who were not currently receiving treatment.
study_duration: Past 30 days (beta test); 3-month follow-up planned for pilot RCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a Mindfulness Childbirth and Parenting (MBCP) intervention on heart-rate variability (HRV), inflammatory biomarkers, and self-assessed mental health in women at risk for perinatal depression.
results_summary: The MBCP intervention significantly reduced perceived stress and increased mindfulness compared to the control group, but it had no significant effect on perinatal depression, inflammatory markers, or HRV measures.
population_specificity: Pregnant women at increased risk for perinatal depression, recruited from maternity health clinics in Stockholm, Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, satisfaction, impact, and limitations of an eight-week mindfulness and compassion course for a multi-professional palliative care team.
results_summary: The course was well-received, with 91% of participants expressing moderate to high satisfaction and willingness to recommend it. Learning gains were highest in knowledge and techniques (38.5-49.4%), moderate in skill implementation (26.2-34.5%), and lowest in attitude changes (12.7-24.6%).
population_specificity: Multi-professional palliative care team employees.
effective_dosage: Not specified (preparatory evening sessions and daily meditation exercises).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and residual EDS.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in EDS for the Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) group, reaching clinical significance, while MBSR participants and trainers identified movement-based exercises as most efficacious. ACT also significantly reduced insomnia symptoms, a secondary outcome.
population_specificity: 16 OSA patients with residual excessive daytime sleepiness (rEDS), reduced to 13 after dropouts.
effective_dosage: Standardized 8-week MBSR program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To synthesize and analyze the evidence on the efficacy of cognitive-behavioral interventions, including Mindfulness, for improving the quality of life in people with pathological gambling.
results_summary: Cognitive behavioral interventions, particularly when combined with Mindfulness or Player Anonymous sessions, improved quality of life, depression, anxiety, gambling behavior, and alcohol consumption, with better long-term results.
population_specificity: People with pathological gambling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an unguided, web-based intervention to increase concreteness-experiential thought (CET) could influence depressive symptoms and enhance protective factors like mindfulness and goal striving.
results_summary: The intervention marginally increased CET and mindfulness tendencies but did not significantly affect depressive symptoms. The effects were small and observed primarily in follow-up assessments.
population_specificity: Healthy university students in Japan
effective_dosage: One psychoeducation session and five CET training sessions over a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mindfulness-based Peak Performance (MBPP) improves athletic performance under pressure and relevant mental attributes compared to self-talk and wait-list control groups.
results_summary: The study expects MBPP to improve performance under pressure and relevant mental attributes more than self-talk, though final results are pending as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: 90 athletes aged 18-30 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) on anxiety, depression, and quality of life in breast cancer patients undergoing postoperative chemotherapy.
results_summary: MBSR significantly improved anxiety (SAS) and depression (SDS) scores compared to routine nursing, with notable enhancements in quality of life (FACT-B scores), though physiological effects were not significant.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients undergoing postoperative chemotherapy (n=225).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of provider-led prenatal stress-reducing interventions, including mindfulness, in improving maternal stress and mood.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness, as part of group-based therapies integrating multiple approaches, showed an increased likelihood of improving maternal stress and mood, though efficacy varied by intervention type and stress targeted.
population_specificity: Pregnant people in the U.S., especially those disproportionately affected by stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness as a behavioral therapy for global symptoms and pain relief in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness, along with other behavioral therapies, demonstrated only modest benefit in improving global IBS symptoms and pain relief. Current evidence suggests limited efficacy compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize empirical research on the role of yoga (a mindfulness-based intervention) in improving biopsychosocial health outcomes for caregivers of persons with dementia.
results_summary: Yoga was found to reduce stress, depression, and anxiety while improving quality of life, vitality, self-compassion, mindfulness attention, sleep quality, and diastolic blood pressure. However, caregiver burden, systolic blood pressure, and heart rate did not show significant changes.
population_specificity: Caregivers of persons with dementia (both informal and professional caregivers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on implementation strategies to increase access and use of evidence-based psychotherapies (EBPs), including mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), for chronic pain and mental health conditions in integrated healthcare systems.
results_summary: The study found that CBT and ACT implementation demonstrated moderate to large improvements in patient symptoms and quality of life, but no studies evaluated MBSR implementation. Provider training increased self-efficacy and EBP use, but impacts on Reach and Maintenance were unclear.
population_specificity: Veterans Health Administration (VHA) and large integrated healthcare systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review digital mental health interventions, including mindfulness, for people with epilepsy to assess their effectiveness in improving mental health and wellbeing.
results_summary: The study identified seven digital interventions based on CBT and mindfulness techniques, showing promising results in reducing depression symptoms and some improvements in anxiety, life satisfaction, and quality of life for people with epilepsy.
population_specificity: Adults, children, and young people with epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of psychosocial interventions, including mindfulness, for family members caring for cancer patients in the palliative period.
results_summary: The study found that mindfulness and other psychosocial interventions improved depressive symptoms, stress levels, caregiver burden, quality of life, self-efficacy, coping skills, and awareness levels in caregivers. However, only 8 out of 4652 articles met the inclusion criteria, indicating limited robust evidence.
population_specificity: Family members caring for patients with cancer in the palliative period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the neural mechanisms and mindfulness-specific effects of MBSR in alleviating depression and anxiety in adults with ASD.
results_summary: MBSR uniquely improved executive functioning and mindfulness traits, while both MBSR and SE reduced depression, anxiety, and autistic traits. Neural connectivity changes were linked to these improvements, implicating the default mode and salience networks.
population_specificity: Adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of brief motivational interviewing plus substance-free activities session plus mindfulness (BSM) versus contingency management (CM) in improving buprenorphine-naloxone adherence in individuals with opioid use disorder.
results_summary: The study proposed to evaluate the relative efficacy of BSM and CM on medication adherence, but results were not yet available as the abstract describes a planned trial. The design will assess whether sequential treatment decisions improve adherence for non-adherent individuals.
population_specificity: 280 adults seeking treatment for opioid use disorder at a university-based addictions clinic.
study_duration: 4 sessions initially, with maintenance intervention for an additional 6 months for adherent participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the evidence on Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBI) for improving biopsychosocial outcomes in individuals with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).
results_summary: MBI was more effective than control groups in short-term improvements in stress, mindfulness, C-Reactive Protein (CRP), and health-related quality of life (HRQoL). Long-term benefits were maintained for stress and mindfulness but not for HRQoL, with no long-term data available for CRP.
population_specificity: Individuals living with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short- and long-term effects of patient education combined with mindfulness/medical yoga on pain, physical function, and quality of life in older adults with spinal osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, painkiller use, social function, balance, and theoretical knowledge, which were maintained at the 1-year follow-up. Mindfulness/medical yoga combined with patient education showed positive effects on physical function and quality of life.
population_specificity: Osteoporotic individuals aged 60+ with one or more vertebral fractures.
effective_dosage: Once a week for ten weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) with relapse prevention (RP) in reducing alcohol consumption and explore potential moderators like sex and cannabis use.
results_summary: Drinking decreased comparably across both treatments, but improvements in heavy drinking days diminished for RP participants post-treatment. Cannabis use moderated treatment efficacy for heavy drinking days and drinks per drinking day.
population_specificity: 182 individuals (48.4% female, aged 21-60) who reported high alcohol consumption but wished to quit or reduce drinking, recruited from Denver and Boulder, Colorado.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) during pregnancy on postpartum mental health, particularly postpartum depression.
results_summary: MBIs significantly improved depressive symptoms in healthy pregnant women but were ineffective for high-risk pregnant women with severe depressive symptoms before delivery. MBIs did not show significant advantages over other intervention methods.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, including healthy pregnant women and high-risk pregnant women with severe depressive symptoms before delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions on physical and psychological outcomes in women with infertility.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that mindfulness-based interventions significantly reduced depression and anxiety symptoms and improved five domains of health-related quality of life (physical function, general health, vitality, role-physical, and social function) in women with infertility.
population_specificity: Women diagnosed with infertility, over the age of 18.
